text: oil and water usually don't mix but when
the two do end up together like in an
oil spill they can be almost impossible
to separate completely material
scientists at the University of Michigan
and the Air Force Research Lab have
teamed up to make a new type of membrane
one that can separate any kind of oil
and water mixture by simple gravity
filtration and they say the membrane
might be particularly useful as an
energy efficient low-cost means of
cleaning up oil spills to make the
membranes the team combined a
water-loving polymer with an oil
repelling silicon based material then
they dipped polyester fabric or
stainless steel mesh into the mixture
and let it dry water dyed blue
completely wets the surface of the
membranes and rapeseed oil dyed red
beads up nearly perfectly in this video
clip the researchers show how the
membrane could be used to continuously
separate a complex oil water mixture
they drip an emulsion made from water
hexa decane and a surfactant onto a
membrane water dyed blue dripped through
the water-soluble surfactant goes along
to hexa decane dyed red exits from the
side of the container
this type of continuous system could be
used to clean up oil spills by skimming
oil from the surface of water in rivers
lakes or oceans and then filtering it
through the membrane it takes a lot of
energy to pump fluid through typical
membranes and they usually get fouled up
by oily material over time limiting
their use the new membranes stay gunk
free through more than a hundred hours
of continuous flow and the researchers
think they can last for the long haul
besides cleaning up oil spills the
researchers envision that their
membranes could be used in wastewater
treatment for fuel purification and to
separate emulsions used in manufacturing
processes
